sections.title: Core Concepts
sections.content: Before learning the flow of a turn, it helps to understand a few key principles that apply throughout the game. These are the foundations of how models interact, measure, and resolve actions in Veilrot.

sections.title: Rolling Dice
sections.content:
All checks in the game use standard six-sided dice (D6). When a rule says to roll, it usually means: roll one or more dice and compare each result to a target number (like "4+," meaning you need a 4 or higher to succeed).

Sometimes you'll see the term natural roll. This means the number showing on the die before any modifiers are added.

  • A natural 1 always fails, even if you have bonuses.
  • A natural 6 always succeeds, no matter the odds.
  • Modifiers (like +1 to Hit) are added to the roll after the roll is made.

sections.title: Line of Sight
sections.content:
To see if a model can target something—like for a ranged attack or ability—you check line of sight. That simply means: can the model see the target?

You can measure this from any point on the model's body or its base. If any part of the target is visible from that perspective (even just an arm or weapon), line of sight is clear. Obstructions like walls or terrain might block it.

sections.title: Measuring Distance
sections.content: All distances—movement, range, abilities—are measured from the edge of one model's base to another. Always base to base.

sections.title: Rounding & Fractals
sections.content:
In Veilrot, you'll never need fractions or decimals. All measurements, calculations, and effects are handled in whole numbers.

If a rule or effect results in a partial number—like 2.5 Wounds or 3.3 inches—always round up to the nearest whole number, unless a rule specifically says otherwise.

Example: A model falls 2.3 inches. That becomes 3" for the purpose of fall damage. Another ability inflicts 1.5 Wounds—this becomes 2.

sections.title: Engagement Range
sections.content:
A model is engaged when it's within 1" of an enemy. Engagement matters because:

  • You can't Move, Dash, or Charge while engaged.
  • You can't make Ranged Attacks or use Special Actions unless a rule says you can.
  • You can still make Melee Attacks, or try to Disengage.

Once you understand these basics, the rest of the game flows much more easily. Keep them in mind—they come up often.

sections.title: Turn Sequence
sections.content:
Veilrot is played in alternating activations, which means players take turns activating one figure at a time instead of controlling their entire warband in one go. This system keeps the gameplay dynamic and interactive, forcing players to respond to evolving battlefield conditions.

Each game round is divided into three distinct phases:

sections.title: Initiative Phase
sections.content: At the start of each round, both players count the number of models in their warband currently on the battlefield. Then, each rolls a D6. The player with the highest result wins the initiative and chooses whether to activate a figure first or allow their opponent to do so. This choice can be critical—sometimes it's better to wait and react, while other times seizing the initiative can swing the tide of battle.

sections.title: Action Phase
sections.content:
Players then take turns activating their figures one at a time. When a figure activates, it can perform up to two actions, such as moving, attacking, or using a special ability. Figures cannot perform the same action twice in a single activation unless specifically allowed by a rule. Once a figure has completed its activation, it cannot act again that round. This continues until all figures from both sides have activated.

This alternating system encourages tactical foresight—players must weigh the risks of leaving figures vulnerable versus capitalizing on opportunities as they arise.

sections.title: End Phase
sections.content: After all figures have activated, the End Phase begins. During this phase, players resolve any lingering effects such as ongoing conditions, scenario triggers, or end-of-round objective scoring. It's also a moment to assess the battlefield and prepare for the next round of conflict.

sections.title: Figure Activation
sections.content:
When a figure activates, it may perform up to two actions. These actions represent everything from careful positioning to brutal combat or strategic ability use. Unless a rule specifically says otherwise, a figure cannot perform the same action twice in a single activation.

Here are the most common actions a figure can take:

sections.title: Move
sections.content:
The figure travels up to its Movement (M) value in inches across the battlefield. This action is often used to reposition, advance toward objectives, or retreat from threats. Movement is affected by terrain and elevation as described in the Movement rules.

A figure cannot end a Move action within 1" of an enemy model.
A figure also cannot perform a Move action while within engagement range of an enemy model.

sections.title: Dash
sections.content:
The figure surges forward in a desperate sprint. Roll a D6 and add the result to the figure's Movement value for this action. However, a figure that Dashes cannot Attack or Charge in the same activation. Dash is ideal for repositioning, escaping danger, or reaching objectives.

A figure cannot Dash while within engagement range of an enemy model.

sections.title: Charge
sections.content:
Charging is the bold act of hurling a figure into close combat, often turning the tide of battle with momentum and force. To declare a charge, first select one or more enemy models within line of sight as your target. Then roll 1D6 and add the result to your figure's Movement (M) value—this total is your charge distance.

If the target is within that distance to the target, move the charging figure toward them, placing it into engagement range (1"). Because of the momentum and aggression behind the charge, the attacker gains +1 to Hit on any subsequent attacks this activation.

If the distance rolled isn't enough to reach the target, the charge fails—the figure remains in place and the action is wasted.

Some weapons and abilities gain bonuses when charging, so always check your figure's traits and gear. A well-timed charge can overwhelm defenses and seize control of contested ground—just be sure the distance isn't too great, or your warriors may fall short and exposed.

Note: A charging figure may not end its movement within engagement range of any enemy model other than its declared targets, following the same restrictions as normal movement.

sections.title: Attack
sections.content:
The figure makes a melee or ranged attack with one of its equipped weapons. Melee attacks require the target to be within engagement range, while ranged attacks must respect line of sight and range bands. Each attack follows the core Hit → Save → Damage → Grit sequence, as described in the combat rules.

A figure cannot make a ranged Attack while within engagement range of an enemy model.

sections.title: Retaliate
sections.content:
"It waits for the blow—and answers with its own."

This model may spend one action during its activation to enter a retaliatory stance. When it does, place a Retaliate token next to it.

If the model is targeted by an attack and survives, you may remove the Retaliate token to make an immediate free attack back against the attacker (melee or ranged, as appropriate).

Only one Retaliate token may be active on a model at a time.

This effect can only trigger once per round, and is lost if the token is not used by the end of the round.

sections.title: Disengage
sections.content:
This action allows a figure to carefully withdraw from close combat. The model may move up to its full Movement value away from any enemy models it is engaged with, so long as this movement ends outside of engagement range of any enemy models.

A figure that performs a Disengage action cannot Move, Attack, Dash, Charge, or use a Special Action for the remainder of its activation.

sections.title: Stand Up
sections.content: Any model that is Prone may use one of its actions to stand up. This removes the Prone condition. Standing up costs effort. Timing it well is key—do you risk standing while vulnerable, or wait for support to arrive?

sections.title: Cover
sections.content:
The figure braces for incoming fire or hunkers behind the environment. This action may only be taken if the model is within 1" of a terrain feature.

While under the effect of Cover, if the model is Obscured by that terrain feature when attacked, the attacker suffers an additional –1 to Hit. The effect lasts until the figure's next activation or until it moves.

A figure cannot take the Cover action while within engagement range of an enemy model.

sections.title: Special Action
sections.content:
Many figures have unique abilities, rituals, or technological tricks listed in their rules. These often take the form of Special Actions and can include anything from healing allies to manipulating objectives or terrain.

A figure cannot perform a Special action while within engagement range of an enemy model.

sections.title: Overreach
sections.content:
"The third step is never stable—but sometimes, it's necessary."

A model may attempt a third action during its activation. This is called an Overreach, and the action taken may be one the model has already performed this turn.

Roll 1D6. On a 3+, the action succeeds and resolves as normal.
On a 1–2, the Overreach fails and the activation ends immediately.

If it fails:
  • The opponent chooses any model on the battlefield (friendly or enemy) that has not yet activated. That model must activate immediately.
  • After that activation, turns proceed as normal.


The Overreaching model suffers the following penalties until the start of your next turn:
  • Its Claim is reduced to 0
  • All attacks targeting it may reroll failed Hit rolls


Understanding which combination of actions best suits a situation is the heart of Veilrot's tactical depth. Whether you push forward aggressively, hold your ground, or use battlefield manipulation, how you spend each activation defines your warband's success.

sections.title: Movement & Terrain
sections.content:
Movement in Veilrot is measured in inches and is one of the most tactically important parts of the game. A figure's Movement (M) stat defines how far it may travel when performing a Move or Charge action.

Models move freely across open ground, but terrain and elevation introduce key restrictions and opportunities.

Figures cannot move through other models unless they have a special rule that allows it. Likewise, most models may not end their movement overlapping another base, on impassable terrain, or in mid-air.

sections.title: Terrain Effects
sections.content:
Difficult terrain, such as rubble, thick fungus, or waterlogged ground, costs double movement to cross.

For example, moving 2 inches through difficult terrain would cost 4 inches of movement. Figures can still move out of or around such terrain if they have the remaining movement to do so.

Vertical movement, such as climbing up walls or over obstacles, also costs double movement. Additionally, a model cannot move more than 3 inches vertically in a single direction during a single activation, unless it has a rule or equipment that states otherwise.

A model may not end its movement while partway through vertical traversal; it must fully complete the vertical move or remain where it started.

This creates meaningful decision-making when traversing multi-level battlefields and rewards strategic use of terrain, ladders, and elevation rules. Some warbands or figures may possess special rules to ignore or reduce these movement penalties, making them especially mobile or evasive in ruined environments.

sections.title: Fall
sections.content:
Sometimes a model ends up somewhere it didn't mean to be—knocked from a ledge, pulled by an ability, or simply misjudging a drop. In Veilrot, falling hurts.

Whenever a model falls from a height, it suffers 1 point of damage for each full inch fallen, minus its Strength stat.

• Only full inches count—round down if needed
• This damage can't be blocked by Save rolls
• However, the model still rolls Grit checks as normal to try and resist the incoming harm

Example: A model with Strength 3 falls 5". It takes 2 damage (5 – 3 = 2). It then rolls 2 Grit checks—one for each point of damage.

If the Strength value is equal to or greater than the fall distance, the model hits the ground hard but uninjured. You can imagine it rolling with the impact, digging into the terrain, or simply being built to survive worse.

A model taking damage in this way is also knocked Prone.

sections.title: Prone
sections.content:
A model that becomes Prone has been knocked off its feet, staggered to the ground, or otherwise thrown out of fighting stance. This condition limits the model's options severely until it recovers.

While Prone:
  • The model can't perform any actions other than Stand Up
  • It can still be targeted by attacks and abilities
  • It counts as Engaged if within 1" of an enemy, but cannot make Melee Attacks until it recovers

Being Prone represents loss of footing, momentary collapse, or being driven to the ground by force. It's dangerous to stay that way—especially near enemies.

sections.title: Collide
sections.content:
Sometimes, a model is shoved, hurled, dragged, or launched—and ends up crashing into something else. In Veilrot, when a moving model involuntarily collides with another model, the result is often bruising, bone-snapping, or worse.

A collision occurs when a model is forced to move and ends its movement overlapping the base of another model. This can happen from knockback effects, pull abilities, terrain shifts, or being flung by explosions or relic effects.

When a collision occurs:
Both models suffers Wounds equal to:
[enemy model's Toughness] + [distance moved] – [its own Toughness]

sections.title: Common Abilities
sections.content:
Combat in Veilrot is intense, personal, and layered. It's not just about who swings first or who wears thicker armor—it's about positioning, momentum, and the desperate edge between life and death.

Every time a model makes an attack, it unfolds in two linked stages: the Clash, where weapons meet resistance, and the Suffering, where consequences take root.

Understanding this sequence—what it tests, what it rewards—is key to mastering the battlefield.

sections.title: Last Stand (X+)
sections.content:
Once per battle, when this model's Wounds are reduced to 0, roll a D6. On a result of 5 or higher, it survives the attack sequence with 1 Wound remaining.
Triggers after Grit checks, before the model is removed.
Only works once per battle.

sections.title: Guarded
sections.content:
When an enemy allocates hit rolls to this model, you may choose to redirect all of them to a single friendly model within 2".
Declare this before any Save rolls are made.
You must redirect all hits—you can't split them between models.
This lets nearby allies step in and take the hit—whether through duty, desperation, or design.

sections.title: Brutal Impact (X+)
sections.content: After completing a Charge, roll 4D6 against a target of the charge. Each roll of X or higher deals 1 damage.

sections.title: Bloodthirsty
sections.content: After this model kills a target in melee, it may immediately make a melee attack against another enemy in engagement range.

sections.title: Anchored
sections.content: This model cannot be pushed, pulled, or moved by enemy effects unless explicitly stated. It also cannot be displaced by terrain shifts, forced movement, or objective interactions unless specified.

sections.title: Honed Reflex
sections.content: This model may make a ranged attack even after performing a Dash during the same activation. The attack suffers –1 to Hit unless the weapon has the Balanced or Light trait.

sections.title: Frenzied Rush
sections.content: This model may declare a Charge even after performing a Dash during the same activation. If the Dash added 4" or more, it gains +1 Attack Dice on its first melee attack that activation.

sections.title: Iron Grasp
sections.content:
"What others wield with effort, it handles with ease."
This model may treat two-handed weapons as one-handed for all purposes.
It may equip a second item in the off-hand, such as a shield or another weapon.
It does not reduce the weapon's Strength, Damage, or any other stats.
The model must still meet any other restrictions for equipping the weapon.
This ability has no effect on ranged weapons unless otherwise stated.
